element.name: Martello's & Mounds by Windsockers, Multi-cache (1.5/2)

long-description.p: The Irish coastline is dotted with the famous Martello Towers, small round towers with flat roofs. These towers were designed and built as lookout posts during the Napoleonic Wars. Should an invading ship be spotted by one of the lookouts in the tower, he would make his way to the roof and set fire to a bundle of wood.
This signal would eventually be seen by the next tower location, who in turn would do the same until all the towers along the coast would be notified of an approaching unidentified vessel.

One of twelve such fortifications in north County Dublin, the remains of one Martello tower can be seen at the coast in Balbriggan. The towers were erected between 1804 - 1815 in response to rumours of a Napoleonic invasion, which never took place. Named after their prototype at Cape Mortella in Corsica these formidable bastions possessed 8 feet (2.4m) thick walls. With a large cannon was mounted on a traversing carriage on the roof. The towers never did fire a shot in anger and they fell into disuse. Some 39 still survive in Ireland, many around the Dublin area.

Nearby, in ruinous condition, are two boat houses the larger of which was used for many years as a Sea Bath House, and was much frequented by visitors to the town. The nearby park was once the site of an imposing Coast Guard Station built around 1864, and destroyed during the Irish War of Independence in 1922.

There are plans to build the new Irish seal rescue center on lands donated by Fingal county council near the Martello tower. http://www.irishsealsanctuary.ie/ and also restore the ruins of the coast guard station.

The oldest known verified site in the area is in the townland of Bremore (from the Irish Big Hills) - situated on the coast just north of the town. According to its records, its name is derived from five mounds. Locally known as the Fairy Mounds, these mounds were surveyed in 1960 and have been identified as passage graves of the same era as Newgrange, Knowth, and Dowth of the Boyne Valley (around 2500 BC).

Of the five mounds the central on is the largest at over 3m tall and 30m across. The other four appear to be satellite tombs to this one. There may have been more to the north of the main mound at one time, but these would have been washed into the sea so we'll never know.
To find the cache you must visit the Martello tower near the above location and note the number of open windows with ledges call this number A
Go to N53 36.875 W006 11.112 take note of the number of this bridge and call the answer B.C.D
To find the cache go to N53 A(A+B).D(A+D+A) W006 (A+D).B(C-A+B)(D-C+B)
The cache is a small sized container please rehide it well as Muggles frequent this area.

element.additional-waypoints:
S1ZZG6 - Stage 1
N 53° 36.957 W 006° 10.992
note the number of open windows with ledges call this number A
S2ZZG6 - Stage 2
N 53° 36.875 W 006° 11.112
Take note of the number of this bridge and call the answer B.C.D
S3ZZG6 - Final Location
N/S __ ° __ . ___ W/E ___ ° __ . ___
To find the cache go to N53 A(A+B).D(A+D+A) W006 (A+D).B(C-A+B)(D-C+B)

ul.li:
2010-03-21T15:09:54Z : Found it by orangetigerprawn
I'm sitting on top of the mound having found the cache. The walk out was great now that spring seems to have finally arrived. Listening to the seagulls and the gentle lapping me the waves and watching the fishing boats it wouldn't surprise me if Finbar Furey turned up to play the tin whistle.
Now for the walk back.
Tftc.

2010-03-16T19:00:00Z : Found it by Mausfallensteller
Such a nice place, and that few visitors, it's a pity!
When I'd calculated the final first I was wondering "?", then read the description again, and [:D]. It's worth walking alonge this nice landscape.
in: TB Mike's Racer out: TB Travelling Bank
Thanks for showing this superb view! [;)]

2009-08-19T19:00:00Z : Write note by Petr Skacha
we put there the TB traveling bank

2009-08-02T19:00:00Z : Found it by Petr Skacha
Second try to find it. Found instantly on zero point, just in place where I didn't find it for first time.

2009-05-29T19:00:00Z : Found it by kazidrat
Lovely sunny day, nice walk... TFTC...[:D]

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Martello's & Mounds
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
The Martello Tower

The Irish coastline is dotted with the famous Martello Towers, small round towers with flat roofs. These towers were designed and built as lookout posts during the Napoleonic Wars. Should an invading ship be spotted by one of the lookouts in the tower, he would make his way to the roof and set fire to a bundle of wood.

This signal would eventually be seen by the next tower location, who in turn would do the same until all the towers along the coast would be notified of an approaching unidentified vessel.

One of twelve such fortifications in north County Dublin, the remains of one Martello tower can be seen at the coast in Balbriggan. The towers were erected between 1804 - 1815 in response to rumours of a Napoleonic invasion, which never took place. Named after their prototype at Cape Mortella in Corsica these formidable bastions possessed 8 feet (2.4m) thick walls. With a large cannon was mounted on a traversing carriage on the roof. The towers never did fire a shot in anger and they fell into disuse. Some 39 still survive in Ireland, many around the Dublin area.

Nearby, in ruinous condition, are two boat houses the larger of which was used for many years as a Sea Bath House, and was much frequented by visitors to the town. The nearby park was once the site of an imposing Coast Guard Station built around 1864, and destroyed during the Irish War of Independence in 1922.

There are plans to build the new Irish seal rescue center on lands donated by Fingal county council near the Martello tower. http://www.irishsealsanctuary.ie/ and also restore the ruins of the coast guard station.

The Mounds

The oldest known verified site in the area is in the townland of Bremore (from the Irish Big Hills) - situated on the coast just north of the town. According to its records, its name is derived from five mounds. Locally known as the Fairy Mounds, these mounds were surveyed in 1960 and have been identified as passage graves of the same era as Newgrange, Knowth, and Dowth of the Boyne Valley (around 2500 BC).

Of the five mounds the central on is the largest at over 3m tall and 30m across. The other four appear to be satellite tombs to this one. There may have been more to the north of the main mound at one time, but these would have been washed into the sea so we'll never know.

The Cache

Stage 1

To find the cache you must visit the Martello tower near the above location and note the number of open windows with ledges call this number A

Stage 2

Go to N53 36.875 W006 11.112 take note of the number of this bridge and call the answer B.C.D

Final Location

To find the cache go to N53 A(A+B).D(A+D+A) W006 (A+D).B(C-A+B)(D-C+B)

The cache is a small sized container please rehide it well as Muggles frequent this area.


The Windsockers

Additional Waypoints

note the number of open windows with ledges call this number A
S2ZZG6 - Stage 2
N 53° 36.875 W 006° 11.112
Take note of the number of this bridge and call the answer B.C.D
S3ZZG6 - Final Location
N/S __ ° __ . ___ W/E ___ ° __ . ___
To find the cache go to N53 A(A+B).D(A+D+A) W006 (A+D).B(C-A+B)(D-C+B)
